note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

William Wallace "Judge" Chisolm was a Sheriff, Republican Judge, and outspoken opponent to the Ku Klux Klan in Kemper County, Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born on December 6, 1830 in Morgan County, Georgia, Chisolm moved to Kemper County, Mississippi with his family in 1846. In 1858, he was elected as a justice of the peace, followed by probate judge in 1860. Chisolm is also listed as a merchant and farmer on the 1860 Census Record for Kemper County.

His actions during the Civil War are unclear. One newspaper article reports that he voted for secession and served in the Confederate militia. Another claims that he was a Unionist, but he does not appear to have enlisted in the Confederate Army itself.

Chisolm's actions after the Civil War, however, are much clearer. He became active in Republican politics and was a supporter of Reconstruction, actively opposing the Ku Klux Klan in Kemper County. This included testifying against the Klan's activities to the Congressional committee. From 1869 to 1875, Chisolm served as the county Sheriff, and he received death threats throughout this period. Then in 1875, he was accused of the attempted murder of Judge A. W. Dillard. After his acquittal, Chisolm became increasingly active in mobilizing the Republican Party in Kemper County.

This came to a head on April 26, 1877 when Sheriff John William Gully, a Democrat, was shot and killed near Chisolm's home. Chisolm was later acquitted with the confession of a Black man named Walter Riley, but at the time, Chisolm and two other Republicans (Hoppen and J. P. Gilmer) were arrested and taken to the county jail. Chisolm's family, including his wife and children, and his friend Angus McLellan accompanied him. After reaching the jail, McLellan was shot in the back and a mob of around 300 men surrounded the jail. The ensuing violence ended with the deaths of McLellan, Judge Chisolm, Chisolm's thirteen-year old son John Mann Chisolm, and Chisolm's eighteen-year old daughter Cornelia Josephine Chisolm. Gully's murder marked one step towards the end of Reconstruction in Mississippi, and no charges were filed for Chisolm's murder.

Judge William Wallace Chisolm was married to Emily S. (Mann) Chisolm. The pair had six children, including three girls and three boys. Judge Chisolm died on May 13, 1877 in De Kalb, Kemper County, Mississippi. He was buried in the Riverview Cemetery in Huntingdon, Huntingdon County, Pennsylvania.
(Waukesha Freemen, September 22, 1881; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, June 5, 1875; FindaGrave; Kemper County 1860 Census Record; "Chisolm Massacre," Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Taxation is "the process by which the government of a country obtains money from its people in order to pay for its expenses." (Cambridge Dictionary) During the American Civil War and Reconstruction, the U.S. and Confederate governments expanded their taxation systems to fund their government operations, including military; likewise, states levied their own taxes to fund their respective state governments, including Mississippi. References to Mississippi state taxes and Mississippi residents paying federal taxes are found within this subject tag.

On July 1, 1862, U.S. Congress passed the progressive Internal Revenue Act, and in 1863, the Confederacy likewise authorized a graduated federal income tax that exempted wages up to $1,000, levied a 1% tax on the first $1,500 over the exemption, and 2% on all additional income. Confederate tax systems were even more complicated than the Union's, as states operating under war-time reconstruction governments paid U.S. federal taxes. Income taxes supplemented an already robust tax system that included federal duties, stamp taxes, and fees, among others. Civil War taxes were not immediately repealed at the end of the war but continued until 1872, when President Ulysses Grant's administration sponsored the repeal of most of the "emergency" taxes. (Cynthia G. Fox, "Income Tax Records of the Civil War Years," 18, no. 4 (1986), Genealogy Notes, National Archives)

div.p:
DeKalb, Miss
July 29, 1865

Gov W. L. Sharkey,
Sir,

Some two weeks Since, Mr J T Parker the person who was elected to the office of assessor of taxes in Kemper County, told me that he did not intend to fill the office any longer or rather that he did not intend to accept of the appointment tendered him by your Excellency in your proclamation.
Mr John McRae, of this County, informs me that he intends making application to you for the appointment.
Should you See fit to
appoint him, it will be a good Selection
Very respectfully

Geo L Welsh
Clerk Probate Court.
[Seal]
Mr Parker told me Some Weeks Since, that he did not intend to fil the office of assessor any longer; as he intends leaving the County, and he has left the County.
This appointment of Mr John McRae to the place will be a good appointment

M. D Crawford
Justie of the Peace

From the Statements of Messers Welsh & Crawford I am satisfied that Mr Parker does not intend longer to exercise the duties of his office; and I therefore recommend to your Exc=ellency Mr John Mc Rae; as a person in every way qualified to perform the duties of that office.
Respectfully &c

John. B. Brittain
President Board of Police
I recommend Mr Jno Mc Rae, as a person fully qualified for the office of Assessor of Taxes for this County.

John W Gully Shff
Kemp Co.

Gov—Sharkey.
Sir—Jno Mc Rae informs me that he designed [page torn] application to Your [page torn] for the office of asses
of Tax in Kemper co. He is a Young gentleman well qualified to fill the place and will give general satisfaction ot the people He is a conscientious man and has been all through the rebellion
Yours &c

W W Chisolm
Prob Judge Kemper c

DeKalb Miss
July 31st 1865.
Gov. Sharkey
I am requested by the Sheriff of this County to inquire whether a man Distilling Whiskey and Selling it by the retail is subject to taxation under your late Tax Bill.
Respectfully &c
John [page torn]
